text.p: These are the leading stories in Skopje newspapers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The government will not respond to requests of strikers in the court administration for a 28 percent raise in their salaries. This is the result of negotiations on Thursday between the strike committee and Justice Minister Georgi Spasov.

- From June 25, all Macedonian citizens entering or leaving the country will have to pay 30 denars (1.11 German marks) at border crossings. Car owners will pay 30 denars, motorcycle owners 20, vans 60, trucks and buses 150, and trucks with trailers 200 denars.
- Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov to meet with representatives of Macedonian emigrant associations in the United States during his two-day visit which started on Thursday.
- Supreme Court of Macedonia President Dimitrije Dimiskovski says efficiency and promptness in the work of courts in Macedonia unsatisfactory. Out of 834,000 cases last year only half ruled on.
- Representatives of French company SISTRA on visit to Macedonia, interested in participation in realisation of railway line towards Bulgaria.

- North Atlantic Assembly Ross-Rot seminar opened in Ohrid on Thursday. Representatives of 20 countries attending. "Macedonia fulfills conditions for NATO membership," Macedonian Parliament Speaker Tito Petkovski says in opening address.

- Opposition VMRO-DPMNE party leader Ljupco Georgievski criticized President Gligorov's offer to U.S. President Bill Clinton for the SFOR units, after the end of their mandate in Bosnia, to be transferred to Macedonia. "With this kind of an offer the sovereignty of the Republic of Macedonia is definitively endangered becoming a classic tomato republic," Georgievski said.

- "My party does not have anything against installing U.S. troops in Macedonia and I think the president has the right to make such offers, but still the parliament has to be informed about such an offer," says Liberal Democratic Party leader Stojan Andov.

- The mayors of 25 municipalities governed by members of the Albanian national minority adopt on May 27 a secret declaration according to which the Albanian-language Tetovo University, considered illegal by the government, will be financed from the budget of these municipalities.
